NEBRASKA STATE INSURANCE BOARD 5 LETTER OF TRANSMITTAL LINCOLN, NEBRASKA, Hon. Keith Neville, Governor of the State of Nebraska, Lincoln, Nebraska. Dear Sir: — Pursuant to the provisions of Section 18 of the Insurance Code of Nebraska (G. S. 3154, Revised Statutes, 1913), on behalf of the State Insurance Board, I submit herewith information as required by said section. The first subdivision of Section 18 requires the Board to transmit a statement of all insurance companies authorized to do business in this State during the year ending the 31st day of December next preceding. This will be found in the Summary of Insurance Business as of Decem - ber 31. 1917. The second subdivision of Section 18 requires the Board to submit a statement of the insurance companies whose business has been closed tJnce making the last report. This will be found under th» heading "Companies withdrawn, changed or reinsured during biennium." The third subdivision of Section 18 requires the Board to report the names and compensation of the officers and employees employed by it and the whole amount itemized of the expenses of the Department during such period. This will be found in detail under the heading "Financial statement for biennium ended November 30, 1918." The fourth subdivision requires the Board to report any amendments to this chapter which in the judgment of the Board may be desirable. This is covered under the heading "The Insurance Code." Section 18 provides also that the Board shall report in a con - densed form the statements made to the Board by every insurance com - pany authorized to do business in this state * * * as audited and cor - rected by the Board and arranged in tabulated form or in abstracts or classes according to the kind .of insurance. This portion of the report will be found in two pamphlets entitled, respectively, "Summary of In - surance Business in Nebraska for the Year 1917," and "Summary of In - surance Business in Nebraska for the Year 1918," which summaries were published in 1917 and 1918, respectively. An examination of the detailed report of receipts and summaries thereof will show that during the biennium ended November 30, 1918, there were 440 insurance companies doing business in the State at some portion of, or duriing all of the biennium. The 1917 session of the Legislature amended section 3276 of the Revised Statutes, the same being section 140 of the Insurance Code, whereby foreign insurance companies were admitted to do business in this State after it had filed one annual report to the insurance depart - ment of its home state, instead of four such annual reports aa was re - quired before said amendment. The effect of this amended act has

6 THIRD BIENNIAL REPORT been to admit purely wild-cat companies to enter Nebraska for the pur - pose of effectuating stock selliing schemes. It is therefor recommended that this section be amended so as to require four annual statements of all foreign companies, as provided by the original Insurance Code, as a condition to securing a license to do business in Nebraska. There is no provision in the statutes providing for the supervision of the sale of capital stock of insurance companies, either by this de - partment or any other branch of the State government. It is earnestly recommended that some provision be made for an adequate supervision of this evil. Respectfully submitted W. B. EASTHAM, December 31, 1918. Insurance Commissoiner.

NEBRASKA STATE INSURANCE BOARD 25 RESULTS OF EXAMINATION A. O. U. W The examination of the Ancient Order of United Workmen was started in June of 1917, and disclosed the fact that the organisation was in serious financial difficulty. The outstanding unpaid death claims ex - ceeded, by several thousand dollars, the tangible assets available for pay - ment. This condition was the outgrowth of an inadequate assessment rate schedule and the only possible remedy, an adequate rate, was put into force on May, 1917. Our examination was for the particular purpose of forecasting the results of the increased rate schedule with a view to determining whether the Insurance Board should take the organization's affairs into its hands or allow the officers of the organization to continue in charge. The findings of the examination were such that it was deemed advisable to allow the society to continue under its own management and this was done. The financial condition of the order at the present time justifies the action taken. Conservative Health & Accident Association The examination of this Association made in May 1918, brought to light the fact that the company was insolvent and in a badly run-down con - dition as regards records. The officers of the company had no desire to continue with it and the Board was forced to either take charge and liqui - date the company or find someone who was willing to put the company on its feet financially and continue it. The latter was done, and at the present time, under its new name. Great American Accident Company. Omaha Health & Accident Company The examination of the company as of June 17, 1918, found an insol - vent condition, and after an unsuccessful attempt, on the part of the of - ficers and directors, to rehabilitate the company financially, it was taken over by the Board and is at present being administered by a man responsi - ble to the Board. It is hoped that its affairs will soon be in shape to per - mit of its being reinsured by some one of our home' companies. General Comments The general result of our examinations of Nebraska companies, was highly satisfactory, showing them to be making pleasing progress almost without exception. Our work gave us an opportunity to show some few companies wherein they could keep their records better and more economi - cally and it is due the companies to say that our suggestions were always given consideration and in most instances, acted upon. Some of the companies ask for an examination annually by the department, and in such cases the examination is made although the law requires an exami - nation to be made but once in three years.

26 THIRD BIENNIAL REPORT THE DEPARTMENT HAS TAKEN PART IN THE FOLLOWING JOINT EXAMINATIONS OF COMPANIES LICENSED IN NEBRASKA Belt Automobile Indemnity Association of El Paso, 111., was examined as of June 30, 1918, by the Illinois, Alabama, Colorado, Mississippi, Ten - nessee and Nebraska departments. The Nebraska department was rep - resented by Mr. H. N. Sprague, Examiner. Bankers' Reserve Life of Omaha, was examined as of December 31, 1917, by the departments of Nebraska, Colorado, and Kansas. The Ne - braska department wag represented by Mr. B. R. Bays, Examiner. Central States Life of St. Louis, was examined as of December 31, 1917, by the Missouri and Nebraska departments. The Nebraska de - partment was represented by Mr. B. R. Bays, Examiner. The Commonwealth Life of Omaha, was examined as of Dec. 31, 1917, by the departments of Nebraska and Colorado. Nebraska department was represented by Mr. B. R. Bays, Examiner. The Farmers' Life Ins. Co., of Denver, Colo. In the fall of 1917, a joint examination of this company by the depart - ments of Colorado, Texas, Kansas and Nebraska was started, Nebraska being represented by Mr. B. R. Bays. This examination soon brought to light a bad financial situation in the company, and the four departments mentioned held several conferences on the subject of the company's con - dition and its probable future. As a result of these conferences, the financial trouble was relieved by the stockholders and directors of the company, and the company was allowed to continue doing business in this state. At the present time, the company is still operating under its li - cense in Nebraska, but whether this license is renewed or not for the year 1919, is to be decided by the showing which the company can make as of December 31, 1918. The Globe Life Ins. Co., of Salina, Kans. This company was admitted to Nebraska in May, 1917, on the strength of its condition as shown by the annual statement for the year 1916, and its Certificate of Authority from the Kansas department. During the fall of that year, the company engaged in an extensive stock selling campaign in Nebraska. In February, 1918, the company was examined by the de - partments of Kansas and Nebraska, Mr. B. R. Bays, representing the Ne - braska department and an extremely bad condition revealed. This con - dition seemed to have been the result of indiscretions on the part of some of the officers of the company and this department proceeded to cancel the company's license and the Kansas department applied for and obtained a receivership far the company. The final responsibility for the damage done has not at this date been determined by the courts, but the affairs of the company are still being administered by a receiver appointed by the court and the company has suspended all activity except such as is neces - sary to the maintenance of the business which it had previously acquired. Great Western Accident of Des Moines, Iowa, was examined as of August 31, 1917, by the Iowa, Wisconsin, Colorado, Kansas and Nebraska departments. The Nebraska department was represented by Mr. M. R. Swanson, Examiner.

The license of the company was suspend - ed and another examination was made as of March 31, 1918, at which time the impairment had been made good and the license was issued May 1, 1918. The Nebraska department was represented by B. R. Bays and M. R. Swanson, Examiners.
